With all the uncertainties surrounding the Activision/Infinity Ward debacle that took place back in March 2010, many pondered an inevitable fall from grace for the Call of Duty franchise. With Medal of Honor's impending preempt release, that speculation was still debatable. However, hardly anyone ever considered the opposite. Except for maybe those who were hard at work behind the doors at Treyarch. They were given an opportunity to prove to the naysayers of the Infinity Ward fan club that they could bring the franchise to bigger and better heights. Even with that skepticism, the team at Treyarch knew what was at stake and have made their point very clear.

Call of Duty: Black Ops took a lot of risks by stepping away from the norm, particularly in terms of storytelling. Players primarily take the role of Alex Mason, a man who is being held captive and interrogated for information concerning the Ascension Group. A seemingly random sequence of numbers is being broadcast at an unknown location, and his captors believe he has the answers to unravel their mystery. It's hard to speak too much on the plot's topic without giving away any spoilers, but I will say this; their new formula was a huge success.

The story still has plenty of the blockbuster elements that the franchise is known for, but manages to portray itself in a much more intelligent light. It's not just the typical action for action's sake type of game. The story has a well-written narrative that conspiracy buffs will surely love. Not only that, but the main character has a more vocal presence than any previous Call of Duty. The developers even decided to take a slightly more cinematic approach with the addition of a few cutscenes, rather than having dialogue throughout loading screens to help with the pacing. They managed to keep a good balance between set piece moments as well, which are just as intense as ever. Some of the most brutal melee kills are executed during stealth segments, and I imagine that's why they included an option to turn off graphic" content at the start of the game.

I vividly remember the hype over Call of Duty: Black Ops. Black Ops was going to be the next best thing. It was going to be great, and fix all the problems in the previous Call of Duty games. I wasn’t a COD player at that time, and had a bit of a more balanced view of the release. I knew that Black Ops wasn’t going to be the impeccable masterpiece the COD community was hyping it to be. I believed that, like the games that had come before it, Black Ops was going to have its own fair share of problems too.

I vividly remember the community backlash when the game came out and players finally realized this. Most of the prominent members of the COD community grumblingly played Black Ops because it was the popular thing to do--until they eventually abandoned it and looked back to previous games, waiting anxiously for Modern Warfare 3 to come a savior. The golden age of Call of Duty seemed to be over.

Fortunately (or unfortunately to some) this is not where the story ends; for me, it was the beginning.

I started to play Black Ops in its prime, a few months after it came out. It was my first real Call of Duty game (my only previous experience with the series was Call of Duty 2) and I was excited to play the game most people were playing. I discovered that the communities’ extreme reaction to Black Ops was a bit uncalled for.

I originally braced myself for a pretty awful single player experience, but was pleasantly surprised at the story, plot, and characters. The single player is nothing revolutionary, but the characters are memorable (especially Woods) and the plot was compelling enough to make me sincerely want to see how it ended. I also found the missions, specifically the Vietnam missions, quite fun. Vorkuta is also highly memorable. In short, is a single player experience I could definitely see myself playing yet again.

Co-op is almost equally as fun. Taking out endless waves of the zombified Nazis and other undead, aided by Perk-a-Colas, random mystery box guns, and Pack-a-Punched power weapons is a blast every time. Play with a group of dedicated friends, and let the good times swarm! I don’t like all the maps, but if you have people willing to play with you, then the expansion packs could be worth your money; with that many maps to choose from, I believe it would be difficult not to find at least one map that you all will enjoy playing together. Just a personal thought of mine though-- I wish that there were some kind of progress system in zombies--not just a lets see how many waves we can get through in one game" approach. The amount of points earned in each match could be used as experience points to level up--more like the multiplayer experience. Just an idea

Campaign/Zombies Review

Quite simply, this game has one of the best campaign plots I've ever seen. The 1960's, CIA Black Ops in Russia and the Vietnam War, conspiracies, and a diabolical political plot to topple nations... all taken seriously in a totally immersive and epic experience. The gameplay is varied, indoors and outdoors, from lush tropical jungles to intelligence headquarters buildings, in a number of different historical conflicts. No spoilers, but the whole story is about finding a hidden, classified truth that is as mindblowing as the warheads that threaten to destroy the world. This dynamic and interesting campaign is unmatched, certainly throughout the Call of Duty series, as well as all the games I've played. It may not be the newest game, but the plot is worth it, I guarantee.

Although the plot and story elements alone are enough to warrant a purchase, it is as fun of an ADS FPS as I've ever played, with decent graphics, punchy weapons, and great levels. I've played through the entire game on Veteran Difficulty, the most challenging difficulty, and had an absolute blast. There's not an overwhelming amount of collectables, and they remain found after multiple playthroughs.

The Zombies mode in this game is also great, probably better than Black Ops 2. It's not overly complicated like its sequel, and is just solid and hardy. I'm terrible at Zombies and still loved it. In one level you actually get to play as John F. Kennedy fighting zombies in the US Pentagon. Awesome? Awesome.

One of my favorites! This isn't a review for the multiplayer, but it is also spectacular and they come together when you get black ops.

reviewText:
Black Ops is proof that CoD can be a fun series... When it's handled by Treyarch. Overall an improvement over Modern Warfare 2, while also serving as well written and well performed sequel to World at War. The combat is smoother, it (the game) looks slicker and is more colorful, and the singleplayer is probably the tightest in the franchise up to this point. The multiplayer also remains a highlight, being a huge improvement over the previous titles, and I'd argue better than any of the later titles. It's the single-most solid CoD entry, apart from the original and Modern Warfare.

The few cons, though, primarily rest in the multiplayer. Although it may be the best laid out version of the famous game mode, there are some balancing issues in terms of some weapons; namely the FAMAS. Now, for the most part, if a weapon is over-powered, then use it. The issue with it is the whole leveling up system, which means that newer players either rely on luck, the also powerful MP5K, or try to find maps where there aren't too many FAMAS players.

In addition, the CoD Points system is a great idea, but could have been better implemented. For example, what's the point of obtaining points when all of the weapons are still locked by level requirements? You might earn a  lot of CoD Points, but they're useless if you want a weapon you need several more levels to unlock with. EIther leveleing should open up more than one thing to buy, thus giving you more options to spend your money on at a time in the early and later games (Note that mid game more things do become unlocked at a stime, but this usually centers around different logo layers or reticules, all of which are cosmetic features). Note that when you do buy a weapon, you have all of the attachements unlocked. You just need to spend CoD Points on them. That makes sense, but why only the attachments? This mode could have worked better, but still does some things right. Overall, the redundancy of parts of the point system can still be overlooked.

Ultimately, we're still looking at one of CoD's more solid modern gen entries, and I'd suggest picking it up. Good servers can be difficult to find (There's a ton of so-called Tactical Crouch Servers
date:
and other servers ban game elements outright), but with or without, the singleplayer and the Co-Op Zombies mode are also very fun to play.


(NOTES: Aside from the PC, I've also played this game far more extensively on the PS3 and Nintendo Wii, totalling more than a hundred or more hours)

It has such an addicting factor to get to a higher round, but is also plagued with secrets and a lot to do within each map keeping it mostly fresh and it goes on and on. The Rezurrection also brought the old World at War maps back, which includes my personal favorite map, Der Riese. This rendition of Zombies was also improved from its predecessor, World at War. Although you cannot create your own maps this time, sadly, it provides for an excellent experience. All maps are good and worth playing and it introduces more legendary maps like Ascension and Moon to add to the collection.

Multiplayer - The great thing about this is that its skill based, and encapsulates all methods of playstyle. Maps are a variety of sizes, and each map is its own unique adventure and a change of pace from the last. As much as I'm not a big fan of smaller maps that much, this game has 2-3 which make it a nice change of pace. Guns are balanced, and all do relativley the same thing so that you don't lose a fight simply because of circumstance. Recoil is in the guns, and many battles take place at medium - long range so you need to be good with the gun to get a kill. It moves at just the right speed; you can be in a fight mostly whenever you want but can also pursure flanking and you won't be in a clusterf**k all the time. WMD is also probably the best multiplayer map ever; representative of all playstyles, isn't too small and isn't too big. It also has CoD Points, the best the series has done yet from an unlocking perspective. It's the slow of the fast paced gameplay, exactly what I like. This game is just excellent. DLC's are just as great with maps such as Zoo, Hotel, Discovery and Hazard (remake of Cliffside from World at War).

Bonus: An entire twin stick shooter game is within this game, known as Dead Ops Arcade. This is an absurd amount of fun, and really adds on to the package of this game. Also included is the text based game Zork, which can provide a great past time. In addition, the hidden intel and computer that lets you logon to characters profiles provides for great backstory and nice information for what happend before, during and after and insight into each character.

This is just the best FPS ever. Get it.

reviewText:
The Campaign and Zombies portions of Black Ops 1 have aged quite well and having revisited them (I owned this game before I bought the Steam version) I couldn't point out a single flaw (besides the minor glitch mentioned below) with the PC version of either so if you're looking to buy the game for those I'd totally recommend it, but the biggest part of the game (multiplayer) on the other hand...

Let me start by saying Black Ops 1 has my favorite multiplayer out of any Call of Duty game (World at War is a close second) and the only reason why I'm not recommending this is they botched the PC version of the multiplayer really badly. The perfomance is fine and I didn't encounter any bugs but there are so many important flaws you can't look past in the PC release:

- Some campaign levels have parts with missing lighting (character models are totally black)

- No way to start a public game without buying a dedicated server (Private games are still creatable but you can only play with friends)

- No matchmaking system other than the game randomly picking a dedicated server from the list which may not even be the gamemode you want

- The multiplayer is mostly dead at this point with there being a peak of slightly higher than 500 players at the time of this review's creation with 90% of those being on custom modded lobbies.  The only real servers you will find with people in them are 24/7 Team Deathmatch or Nuketown servers with the only servers that support DLC Maps being based in Japan. This pretty much means its impossible to play any of the DLC content for the game without creating a private game and having a bunch of friends ready to play whenever you are

- No party/party matchmaking system which means you can't search for games with a premade group of friends, you have to all join a random server and be lucky enough to have enough open space to all be on the same team (The 360 and PS3 version had this feature)

reviewText:
One of the most classic CoDs out there and one of the last good ones too. I remember playing this game on the 360 the year it came out and enjoyed the multiplayer and zombies, although as time progressed I ended up forgetting about it and sold my 360. I recently decided to buy it again for the PC off of another website for about $10 since it's still overly expensive on steam and these are my thoughts on it:

CAMPAIGN

Since I never got to finishing the campaign on the Xbox I decided to play it again and actually finished it. Graphics are still pretty impressive for a 5 year old game. The campaign provided amazingly fun gameplay and a very engaging story that kept me playing until the end; I was also really surprised by how intriguing the story was and it was definitely worth the play time I put into completing it. I'm sure a lot of people new to the game will enjoy it as much as I did.

MULTIPLAYER

Multiplayer is enjoyable, although to some it may look like it's just been completely dominated by hardcore game modes which some people might find out of their comfort zone, although softcore game modes still exist it just takes a bit of searching for. Most of the community is mature since most of the CoD kiddies are found on console so no need to worry about 9 year olds screaming into their turtlebeaches.

ZOMBIES

The Zombies game mode is still very enjoyable especially with others and surprisingly it's not that hard to find an online lobby(for me at least). You can also play with your friends which I strongly recommend doing unless you're hardcore and like going solo. If you plan on buying this for the zombies you should also pick up the Rezzurection DLC since they only really give you 3 zombies maps in the base game which can get boring after awhile for some people.

Overall I'd give this game a 9/10 and it was worth the amount I paid. I'd recommend this to any fan of the classic CoDs such as CoD4, WaW etc. or anyone who is a fan of FPS games and/or shooting zombies.

They have set the bar high with Black Ops. Black Ops comes out on top of MW2 with vast improvements and most importantly, dedicated servers for multi-player. A game that can deliver a good story while making the characters feel believable and alive is a rare occasion. If you are a CoD fan, this is a must purchase. If you like FPS, but dislike CoD games. reviewText:
Note:I am not including negatives because they are so minor
Short:It's a CoD game,they are all awesome and addicting.

Long:Call of Duty Black Ops is probably the best CoD game Ive played out of all of the franchise.

CAMPAIGN MODE:
Let us begin with the campaign.The game takes place after World at War and is set in the cold war (1960-70) and you are Captain Alex Mason.While you are playing the events of his war experience,the story is greater as you are being interrogated by an old CIA handler of yours who is trying to get answers to stop the nova 6 attacks.It is crafted in a way that combines kick ♥♥♥,pure war action with a gripping set of characters and story which maintains itself in Black ops 2 and 3.

MULTIPLAYER:
Not really as big as it is nowadays,but it still delivers a fun experience to keep you occupied after campaign along with the bonus mode.It allows you to play a variety of game modes (in fairness some people don't play the objective) which gives you XP.Levelling up unlocks new weapons,attachtments,perks,equipment and personalization items.There is a fairly large amount of tactics you can use,wether it be quickscoping to knifing you can always find atleast 1 way to have fun.And don't worry,it gets better when you play the wager modes or team up with friends to dominate the other team.

NAZI ZOMBIES:
The famous bonus mode of treyarch games,nazi zombies is a fan favourite and an epic carnage to clear the gaps in the awesome storyline.In this mode you can team up with 3 other players/friends or solo to fight off endless waves of the undead,often being Nazis.As you gain points,you can access new areas,purchase badass guns,colas for perks and eventually reach pack a punch to upgrade your gun into a laser shooting super weapon.You can also explore the map to find clues to the eerie storyline or find the map objects that play epic songs to fight zombies to.The characters for each map are also epic,from crazed nazi scientists,to John kennedy to Fidel castro to Robert englund.How long can you survive?

OVERALL:
Honestly the best CoD game ever and another epic installment to the franchise.However if you have access,it would definetly say it is better to play on console (incoming PC master race weebs).

reviewText:
As a Call of Duty fan since the original back in 2003, I've seen the series go through its ups and downs. After the massive disappointment that was Modern Warfare 2, I was extremely skeptical on Black Ops. Good thing I was disappointed here too.

The launch was extremely shaky on PC, but now that they've patched it a few times, the game works pretty well. What you'll find, should you choose to get it, is arguably the best Call of Duty campaign to date. It's dark. It's gritty. It's even disturbing. Most of all though, it delivers the trademark Call of Duty intensity whilst daring to be different. After you've gone through that, there's the return of Zombies mode (which I'm personally not a fan of) from World at War, and the deep multiplayer experience. In fact, Black Ops is the most well-balanced CoD game to date, wherein nothing is too over or underpowered and you have customization options like never before.

Downside? It's the 7th CoD game. It's getting stale.

BO1 has real dedics (MW3 had those too!), so crap like lag-comp or hacks are non-issue here (as long as the admins are ok, but you can always play on another dedic, which isn't exactly the case with newer lobby-only CoDs). Maps are fine, weapons are fine, killstreaks are probably fine. I simply have fun playing it.\n\nHOWEVER! Beware, because the game is quite badly optimized. I couldn't play it for years before I got 270x (which isn't exactly the top GPU, but not the cheapest either). On my old radeon 6850 (and even older nvidias I had) the game was simply unplayable. Insane FPS drops and a bonus mouse lag which made your sensitivity +- random. Not something you'd enjoy in a competitive FPS. Weird, considering BO2 never had any trouble on my previous hardware.

reviewText:
This is one of the best Call of Duty titles. You can clearly see that 3arc care more about the PC verson than IW. Why is this game better that the others?

Singleplayer: The singleplayer takes place in the Vietnam era which is rly interesting. They combine it with a little science fiction and thriller. The athmosphere is rly good thanks to these features. The gameplay is usual cod but the story has more focus on the charaters rather than the war itself. The guns have rly cool sounds and visuals tho the overall visuals are not outstanding.

Multiplayer: Peronally I think this is better than BO2. The setting gives the muliplayer a rly awesome vibe. The maps have old school layout and you can find parts where you can interact with silo doors and stuff. The other thing is there are moving objects like the train, the rockets launches and other stuff which gives you extra immersion.
Last but not least the balance. Best! You can counter any offensive device with perks and equipments. Many player complain about the RC-XD but i bet they didn't use flak jacket.
There are many corrections like they removed juggernaut and the perks that gives more weapon dmg.
Only big problem is the performace cuz it is not very smooth. If you have an older 2 core CPU it can be a pain to run smoothly. But it works fine if you are using promod. Oh i forgot it supports player mods and dedicated servers that u can rent. :)

BO2 is better in performance and the pick10 system is rly cool. The orther stuff are inferior compared to the 1st game.

DLC: If you like zombies you can buy them but don't buy it for muliplayer.


Verdict:

Pro: Setting, Cool Guns, Interesting attachments, nice level design (except nuketown), reflex based twitch shooter, dedicated servers and mod tools

Con: DLC's are pricey and good only for zombies, no FOV silder in singleplayer, performance is not good on older machines

reviewText:
One of the best Call of Duty games out there! It has an amazing campaign, great multiplayer, and amazing zombie maps!

Honestly I would have to say this: DON'T BUY THE DLC UNLESS YOU'RE INTO ZOMBIES! Don't get me wrong the Multiplayer maps are greta in this game. The entire game runs of dedicated servers for Multiplayer and most if not all the DLC servers run off the official Treyarch servers. So why is this a bad thing? NO ONE PLAYS ON THE TREYARCH SERVERS! It's sad really. If you're really that interested in playing the Multiplayer DLC maps then get it on console. Anyway, another problem with this game is that dedicated servers have a lot of stupid rules, a lot of Nuketown 24/7 servers, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ admins for the most part. Another big problem is that not a lot of people play the Wager Matches (Gun Game, Sharpshooter, etc). In general it's pretty hard to find a match of Multiplayer due to the fact not a lot of people actually play the PC version of Black Ops anymore. Which is a shame considering this is one of my favorite COD games!

Anyway enough of me talking negative, let's talk about all the postitives! For one thing, these have amazing and memoriable maps! They're pretty basic due to the fact the entire game is set around the cold war. Some maps you may recognize such as Launch, Nuketown, Firing Range, and Stadium. The guns feel great and are fun to use! And just about every server is a Ground War server so it makes it even more fun! The more people the better right? If I'm not mistaken, this is the first COD game to introduce controller support for the PC. I know. I know. Call of Duty: World at War had controller support by typing in console commands, (Honestly I'm not sure about Call of Duty: 4 Modern Warfare due to the fact I don't have the game as of making this review) but it wasn't as easy as Black Ops. Black Ops gives you the controller options right at the options menu easy as that. Sadly, if you played this game for a long time on console (not me) there is not auto-aim assist what so ever. It's easier to use the Keyboard anyway so whatever. One last thing I have to say is that this is the last Call of Duty game to allow mods. The mods are really fun in this game! There's a mod called Zombie Annihilation mod to pretty much you can play Infected in Black Ops, A reverse and Hardcore Gun Game, and many more! The mods are only for Multiplayer however and not for Zombies, but it's still fun to mess around with!

Overall this game gets a 9/10. I highly recommend it!

Anyway enough of me talking negative, let's talk about all the postitives! For one thing, these have amazing and memoriable maps! If I'm not mistaken, this is the first COD game to introduce controller support for the PC. I know. I know. Call of Duty: World at War had controller support by typing in console commands, (Honestly I'm not sure about Call of Duty: 4 Modern Warfare due to the fact I don't have the game as of making this review) but it wasn't as easy as Black Ops. Black Ops gives you the controller options right at the options menu easy as that. Sadly, if you played this game for a long time on console (not me) there is not auto-aim assist what so ever. It's easier to use the Keyboard anyway so whatever. One last thing I have to say is that this is the last Call of Duty game to allow mods. The mods are really fun in this game! There's a mod called Zombie Annihilation mod to pretty much you can play Infected in Black Ops, A reverse and Hardcore Gun Game, and many more! The mods are only for Multiplayer however and not for Zombies, but it's still fun to mess around with!

Overall this game gets a 9/10. I highly recommend it!

reviewText:
Treyarch's surprisingly good campaign set in the Cold War.

Built on the Modern Warfare 2 engine, Black Ops takes a similar approach to the gameplay style - that is, very different from the older Call of Duty titles - while fixing most of the things that Modern Warfare 2 did wrong, adding a bunch of cool new things and moving the setting to the Cold War. That's pretty much it in a nutshell.

Before playing through the campaign for the first time, I was pretty sceptic about it, but needless to say it blew those bad expectations away pretty quickly. It's packed with action at every single step and tells the story in a way that sucks you in like a high-wattage vacuum cleaner, which really was a pleasant surprise from Treyarch as I was expecting something more along the lines of World at War. I would recommend playing through it if you haven't done so yet, it's not going to eat so much of your time since it's Call of Duty, and there were quite a few memorable moments to justify it.

As I mentioned earlier, the multiplayer comes with many improvements over Modern Warfare 2. The entire thing feels more balanced, requires more skill rather than grenade-launching your way to victory and while the killstreaks can feel overpowered at times, it's nowhere as bad. There's also this 'money system' that you use to purchase guns and custom emblems and whatnot - I myself haven't managed to find the actual purpose of it but if you're a fan of such things, it's cool. And, of course, the Zombies mode makes for loads of fun as well.

Overall, it's a good game. Buy it if it's currently on sale or something. Truly don't go for the full price. Like really, no. Buy it on sale.

I've been a very big fan of Call of Duty since its fourth release (Modern Warfare), and Black Ops is my second favorite after CoD4. Weapons are, for most, well balanced and so are the different perks and abilities you unlock. 15 prestige levels that will keep you competing with your friends for the highest title.

Second instance of Nazi Zombies with over 10 maps available and an insane amount of secrets to uncover and techniques to develop. If you don't buy Black Ops for its campaign or its multiplayer, you need to buy it for its zombie mode.

P.S. Try a knife/sniper only server if you ever get bored.

reviewText: I'll summarise Call of Duty Black Ops by highlighting the important points. Yes Black Ops has a strong cinematic singleplayer, with better characterisation and plot than World At War. Yes, Black Ops has made an intricate improvement to the zombies  mode, adding depth and the amount it has to offer. And yes, Black Ops on PC DOES have dedicated servers which eliminates the need for matchmaking and host transition. Yet despite this, the game's no better than COD 4. It does nothing new for the COD series, murdering the quality of the weapons, killstreaks and general balancing of COD's multiplayer. The COD points system is too shallow for what it promises and once again Call of Duty has a deadly short single-player lifespan too. The nail in the coffin for many though would be the outrageous system spec required for the game to run properly. Even a mid-range PC would struggle to play Black Ops without stuttering a chunk load and this is unacceptable. Get Battlefield Bad Company 2 instead.
